column3: Question everything. Learn something. Answer nothing.
If history repeats itself, and the unexpected always happens, how incapable must Man be of learning from experience.
The learning process continues until the day you die.
I'm not afraid of storms, for I'm learning how to sail my ship.
Curiosity is the wick in the candle of learning.
He who would learn to fly one day must first learn to stand and walk and run and climb and dance; one cannot fly into flying.

Life is a series of experiences, each one of which makes us bigger, even though sometimes it is hard to realize this. For the world was built to develop character, and we must learn that the setbacks and grieves which we endure help us in our marching onward.
I am not afraid of storms for I am learning how to sail my ship.
A child's learning is a function more of the characteristics of his classmates than those of the teacher.
I am always ready to learn although I do not always like being taught.
A little learning is a dangerous thing; Drink deep, or taste not the Pierian spring.
If I were given the opportunity to present a gift to the next generation, it would be the ability for each individual to learn to laugh at himself.
The person you consider ignorant and insignificant is the one who came from God, that he might learn bliss from grief and knowledge from gloom.
We now accept the fact that learning is a lifelong process of keeping abreast of change. And the most pressing task is to teach people how to learn.
To make no mistakes is not in the power of man; but from their errors and mistakes the wise and good learn wisdom for the future.
I never learned from a man who agreed with me.
Research is formalized curiosity. It is poking and prying with a purpose.
Losers live in the past. Winners learn from the past and enjoy working in the present toward the future.
Surround yourself with good people. Whether they're the best or not, people are capable of learning if they've got good hearts and they're good souls.

He will therefore have to use what knowledge he can achieve, not to shape the results as the craftsman shapes his handiwork, but rather to cultivate a growth by providing the appropriate environment, in the manner in which the gardener does this for his plants.
Learning without thought is labor lost; thought without learning is perilous.

There is this tremendous body of knowledge in the world of academia where extraordinary numbers of incredibly thoughtful people have taken the time to examine on a really profound level the way we live our lives and who we are and where we've been. That brilliant learning sometimes gets trapped in academia and never sees the light of day.

My father is a real idealist, and he's all about learning. If I asked for a pair of Nikes growing up, it was just a resounding 'No.' But if I asked for a saxophone, one would appear and next day and I'd be signed up for lessons. So anything to do with education or learning, my father would spare no expense.
I feel the older I get, the more I'm learning to handle life. Being on this quest for a long time, it's all about finding yourself.

Collaboration is important not just because it's a better way to learn. The spirit of collaboration is penetrating every institution and all of our lives. So learning to collaborate is part of equipping yourself for effectiveness, problem solving, innovation and life-long learning in an ever-changing networked economy.
Success in management requires learning as fast as the world is changing.
